thread.title: Woolworths ditches Cheap Cheap birds as profit dives

title: Woolworths ditches Cheap Cheap birds as profit dives
text:

Woolworths results reveal company's turmoil

Replay video Return to video Video settings Please Log in to update your video settings
Woolworths results reveal company's turmoil Supermarket giant appoints a new chair as it announces a full-year net profit dive of 12.5 per cent.
PT1M23S 620 349 Autoplay On Off Video feedback Video settings Beleaguered supermarket giant Woolworths has ditched the Cheap Cheap birds as it tries to win back customers and recover ground from rival Coles.
Woolworths has suffered a 12.5 per cent slump in its full-year net profit to $2.15 billion, its first full-year net profit drop in 19 years (excluding one-offs), as it battles to fend off a sustained price attack from Coles, stem losses from its Masters hardware operation and turn around Big W.
Total group sales were down 0.2 per cent to $60.7 billion and earnings before interest and tax plunged 12 per cent to $3.3 billion.
Quarterly food and liquor sales were even worse than expected, falling 0.9 per cent and opening up the biggest gap to date with arch rival Coles. Photo: Steven Siewert
The quarterly food and liquor sales were even worse than expected, falling 0.9 per cent and opening up the biggest gap to date with arch rival Coles.
Advertisement Coles reported a 4 per cent jump in like-for-like food and liquor sales for the same period.
The losses from Masters continue to grow, blowing out to $245.6 million for the full year on sales of $930 million. Last week, the rival Bunnings hardware chain unveiled a record $1.1 billion profit result , from an 11.6 per cent jump in sales to $9.5 billion.
The appointment of former Lion Nathan chief Gordon Cairns as chairman is seen by analysts as a vital step in preparing the ground for the appointment of a new chief executive to replace the retiring Grant O'Brien .
Woolworths did not provide any detail on this process except to say that Mr Cairns would participate in the CEO search process.
Retail analysts had speculated it would be difficult for Woolworths to attract a new CEO without a new chairman.
Woolworths chair Ralph Waters will step down as of September 1.â€‹
The result was in line with the profit warning issued by the 91-year-old company in June when it announced Mr O'Brien's departure.
More to come
